Actually with large inductive charging towers, vehicles, robots, even tractor trailers and things the size of buildings can remain airborne in perpetuity with current technology. Small drones like this could swarm by the thousands 24/7, 365 as long as a charging towers were placed close enough to satisfy the limitations of the storage solution. Most of the existing power grids have some infrastructure in towers tall enough to facilitate this process already. The tech is cheap, and light weight enough to just be mounted anywhere.

We could be floating tractor trailers along grid lines instead of maintaining a multi trillion dollar infrastructure project that was ill conceived at the outset here in the US. Wouldn't even take much. 6% of the Interstate highway system converted to the task of harvesting solar energy is enough to supplement the energy grid with enough surplus to power the permanent levitation of the entire US freight industry. Including all the trains, trucks, airlines. And the cost in material and technology is less per square foot then just expanding highways to meet growing demand, even though it could cost 50x as much and still be quite a lucrative ROI.

It wouldn't even take much considering the mind annihilating scale of the freight industry as it currently exists. It would save trillions of dollars by consolidating it all to a single energy source let alone using Solar energy as the input being ultimately fueless.

Should never have used automobiles and personal transportation trends to form the national infrastructure. Just like this delusional dependence on energy storage we pretend underpins all of modern society. The Sun rises every day, everywhere that matters. There's no reason to consolidate energy, and then sell it back in single servings at a convenience store. Not when the Sun is in absolutely zero danger of falling out of the sky.

I don't think that humans make a few or a dozen adjustments in a short amount of time. I would think that everything we do requires thousands or millions of adjustments or even more. I am speculating but considering that the things we do are conscious and subconscious. The best example I can come up with is when I broke my ankle. Learning how to walk (something I have been doing for more than a decade) was strange. I did not know how much pressure to put on each foot, I did not know how to walk like normal, I did not know which muscles to use both consciously and subconsciously. The first time I took off my cast my foot just flopped out to the point where I was nervous it was going break or pull a muscle. I don't know how to say this but if you do break your ankle you will understand that there is more to something as basic as walking than you think.

Derek,

It would be a huge chad move to directly address Tom Nicholas's video concerning boundaries between independent content, sponsored content with editorial independence, and sponsored content dictated by the sponsor.

You simply CANNOT do something like make a video address the "replication crisis" in academia, or talk about the importance of truth, independence, and critique/criticism in science, without HONESTLY and DIRECTLY addressing the mounting concerns of viewers AND many creators: the issue of editorial independence when corporate sponsorship goes beyond a clearly delineated 1-minute sale pitch and enters the realm of corporate sponsors dictating and directing the arguments, evidence, and conclusions of the video, while using Derek (and other creators) as the "trustworthy" mouthpiece to deliver the talking points of a corporate public relations campaign.

Not only is this DISGUISING the nature and degree of corporate influence over the substance of such "sponsored" (i.e. delivered) videos, it is also directly obscuring what should be clear and delineated boundaries between Derek's independently vetted facts/opinions and talking points delivered directly from a corporate campaign and spoken as if they are Derek's vetted appraisal of the facts.

This is a horrifying evolution of a horrifying development in modern media and their failure to shore up the vitally important base of facts, evidence, and reported news.... the public shared base of information upon which our shared sense of consensus reality is based. Since the advent of cable news, and the FCC relaxing guidelines on broadcast television news requiring certain percentages of news time be devoted to the opposing viewpoint, since then, the collective high standards of truth in media labeled as "news" have steadily decayed. Not only is the basis for verifying true statements often bypassed or slacked on (particularly in conservative cable news and news subject to heavy oversight by their corporate owners), but the lines between factual reporting, opinion pieces, and "entertainment news" are every day becoming more meaningless.

And this development on YouTube, while not new, represents a deepening of the problem. After factual reporting gives way to poorly notated opinion pieces, and opinion pieces giving way to outright "Entertainment """News"""" which doesn't even carry the requirement of a basis in truth, the next step is "native advertising".

Native advertising is advertisement or opinion pieces presented to look like factual news, often with only a tiny indication of being an ad... or increasingly, none at all.

Derek, you and other creators accepting corporate sponsorship, but allowing the corporations to guide and dictate the content of their videos, this is nothing more than Native Advertising.

Native Advertisement trades on the trust built up by a newspaper or magazine... or YouTube channel.... in order to bestow that sense of trust and uncritical acceptance onto the advertised product.

It lessens your channel, Derek. It destroys the trust you have built.

You MUST make a video DIRECTLY addressing this, and this video MUST clearly delineate when and when not you are willing to allow corporate sponsors to dictate the content of a video.

If you want the capability to fly, then your load is reduced by the weight of the legs.  Your speed is also reduced. The large yellow pieces appear only for looks but increase weight and increase drag in the wind, so unclear why they include those.

We have flying drones, and we have bad walking robots. Combining this is no improvement, cause both benfits count, and the disvantages of both systems push each other more relevant than on the single options.
Legs are for whight, energy saving, stability, and possibly stealth, depending on usage. Rotors are non of this and add vulnerability and whight. A system that fits to mutlible requirements tend always to peform less good. So even there would be any use for a walking bot to fly - add a flying drone to grab and deliver it in the circumstances the benefits of such an unstable combiniation exceeds the disvantages.

a common f7 flight controller (based on ARM chipset, same as most smartphones) sold today for less than 40/50 euros has incredible computing power. the described 200hz computation allowing the robot to keep steady are nothing compared to what current flight controllers are able to output, along with the bunch of open source firmwares able to manage them (betaflight, emuflight, inav to name a few). I feel like the experiment here is definitely interesting but far from being "revolutionary" hardware-wise. I wonder what rc protocol they use on the radio... it looks like one of those spektrum radios, maybe deviationTx...

edit: i forgot to mention that the "drone" they used to show how wind affects uav's is probably one of those toy-grade cheap chinese drones, waay underpowered if compared to the ones used for fpv or cinematics...

I think the reason people think it's cheating is that making a control system for a quad set of propellers is super easy compared to the control system for something purely bipedal. It's easy physics to just counter roll and pitch, but making something walk and controlling center of mass is significantly more impressive. Like yeah, it's nice to have both modes of transportation, but there are so many better methods of doing that. The legs are basically fancy looking landing gear, which if you look at the controlled hydraulics of some modern planes, you already see. I'm more interested in seeing Boston Dynamics add a jetpack to their already functioning walkers. I guess hope to see something more seamless in the future though, I guess you have to start somewhere.

It does not walk on its legs. It does not even balance on its legs (squatting stationary on four points of contact is not balancing). It does not resist being blown away by the wind by leaning into it like any other creature that stands on its legs. It's loud so it can't search inside of a semi-collapsed structure and hear someone in need. It will blow dust around everywhere it goes rendering machine vision useless, even more than a regular drone, because it requires more thrust to stay aloft (heavier).
It is a solution in search of a problem, and I cannot think of one practical application for it.

re: slacklining

How long did it take you to learn to ride a bike? How easy and automatic is it now?

On Smarter Every Day, someone made a reverse steering bike for Destin. After a while, he was able to ride it. What he had to do (unconsciously) was to reverse the reflexes that he had learned as a child.

Instead of having a processor crunching data and recalculating everything 500 times a second, we have reflexes -- what some call 'muscle memory.' Whether it's walking, riding a bike, typing, or playing an instrument, we practice until we develop those reflexes.

So if you really want to learn to slackline; practice, practice, practice. Eventually, you will be as stable on that line as you are when walking or riding a bike

It won’t be blown away because of the ground contact, neither will a well designed all terrain vehicle or rc car, yes it can fly but what’s to stop people putting a drone on top of an rc car, the motors and propellers are always running so will use a lot of power so it won’t have a long runtime, on top of that you have to have all the motors or actuators for the legs be under the max take off weight. This would probably be blown about more than a drone in the air due to the extra surface area and with such a large surface area away from the centre of mass the drone part will need to do a lot of compensation to keep it level in high winds.

Much more effective would probably be a quadrupedal or Hexapod robot which doesn’t need the propellers on to walk and can fold up and have a very low profile with the drone.

This is just unnecessary, most drones could land anywhere this one can and have a further range or to make a drone be able to land on more uneven terrain, even though they already can, you could have spring loaded telescopic legs. The added complexity of walking is made easier by the stabilisation from the propellers but still a drone on top of an roc car could probably do as much as this and more efficiently.

As someone who dabbles in slack lining, it’s interesting how Leonardo bounces on the line, which I’ve found is a helpful technique for humans as well. Bouncing negates some of the side-to-side movement of the line, and allows you to stay more upright and stable. Once you get better, you learn to ride with the line, but as a beginner, bouncing definitely helps you to learn.

Quick tips for slacklining: it's actually easier to start in the middle of the line instead of at either end (the swing is slower and you can swing farther to either side, which helps with balance). Put one foot on the line lengthwise and quickly stand up on it. It's usually easier to balance with only one foot on the line, allowing you to flag out your other foot along with both arms to move your center of gravity around. I find narrower lines easier, with 1" wide being my sweet spot, but 5/8" being bouncier and more fun.

I bet humans are doing a LOT more computations every second than that drone with legs.

I love this channel, but this video really upset me. You’re better than this. That drone robot is crap. Blipping the drone rotor speeds to make the robot look like it is bouncing on the wire… it is FLYING. Hold on to a helicopter and try to replicate walking on that rope. I think you’ll find it a LOT easier.

And what was the point of using all those computer fans? They’re not exactly wind tunnel testing it, and a simple single motor shop fan (ie large) would provide plenty of wind to test the stability of the drone. Heck, the drone-bot even FELL OVER when it got low to try to land in a slight breeze!

And btw, skateboarding backwards is very common amongst skaters: you go up a ramp one way, then back down the opposite way - not to mention the countless tricks that involve spinning the board and ending up skating goofyfoot. And the drone could “do it” bc it is a drone. They can fly forwards or backwards or side to side with ease.

Surprised ZERO science was done to simply debunk this fake-bot. Put the whole thing on a scale to weigh it, then have it “walk” on a large scale and let’s see how much of that drone is walking and how much is actually supported by flight. I’m betting the majority of the weight is supported by the drone hovering. Then simply move the legs and make it look like it is walking. Turn the rotors off and let’s see it walk. Uh huh.

Human's pure reaction time and reflexes are quite slow. This is why when we get better at something, like riding a bike, skateboarding, slacklining etc., we are not actually improving our reaction time or reflexes, we commit those experiences to our memory and start to assume or predict what comes next. So when you actually get used to doing those activities, you look like you're reacting really fast, but in reality, you're actually predicting what is suppose to happen next and prepares for that. That's why when something odd happens out of our expected results, an accident happens because not only is our reaction time slow, but our brain is already telling our body to do what it's suppose to do next, instead of just purely using all that processing power for reacting.

I don't like being a skeptic, but some of the things they say they want to do...
Getting a robot like this to fly on Mars is not going to work. The atmosphere on Mars is 100x thinner than ours. You need air to generate lift. The Ingenuity drone is 19 inches tall with four foot diameter propellers spinning at 2400 rpm. They had to redesign computers and other electronic parts to keep the robot light enough to take off.

This is a cool tech demo, but a walking-flying robot is about as practical as a flying car. We've built flying cars -- vehicles that can both drive and fly. They're invariably bad at one or the other (or usually both). There are plenty of companies working to make "flying cars" -- by which they actually mean new designs that work like a helicopter, but better.

Sigh. This thing is cool, but it isn't the future. I skimmed through the paper. Nowhere did I find anything about how long LEO could fly. A couple quotes from the paper:

The nominal walking speed of LEO is 20 cm/s

We investigated its cost of transportation (CoT), a dimensionless quantity characterizing the energy efficiency of locomotion. For LEO, the measured CoT was 108 when walking at a speed of 20 cm/s. When flying at 1 m/s, the CoT was 48, and it decreased to 15.5 at the flight speed of 3 m/s.

Tilting the propeller thrust forces inward increases the moment the propellers can produce about the ground contact point, which improves the controllability for balancing and walking motions. However, there is a trade-off to be made, because larger tilt angles also reduce the net vertical thrust and flight efficiency. It is also possible to vary the tilt angles of the propellers with additional actuators while LEO is walking or flying to improve its performance. However, this was not done for LEO, because this feature would add extra weight and complexity.

LEO with more rigid legs would require less thrust for preventing excessive leg deformation. Furthermore, LEO could walk with the reduced support from the propellers by adopting finite feet for better stability or higher power motors with torque control for joint actuation that would allow for fast and accurate enough foot position tracking to stabilize the walking gait. In such a case, propellers may need to turn on only when the legs fail to maintain stability on the ground without having to run continuously. These solutions would cause a weight increase and lead to a higher energy consumption during flight maneuvers, but they would lower energy consumption during walking. In the case of LEO, we aimed to achieve balanced aerial and ground locomotion capabilities, and we opted for lightweight legs. Achieving efficient walking with lightweight legs similar to LEO’s is still an open challenge in the field of bipedal robots, and it remains to be investigated in future work.


And for a last piece of fun, LEO has a weight of 2.58 kg (5.7 lbs). He isn't going to be carrying your groceries for you.

Thank you for another excellent upload! The term "cheating" is mentioned a couple of times in this video and I struggle with accepting that concept in context with technology of this type. Humans have had billions of years of evolution to develop the locomotion that we use today. The goal of building a tool is to use all of the knowledge and technology available to create the most efficient solution possible. In cases such as this, "Intelligent Design" (not the religious argument) is very much the correct approach and everything that IS possible SHOULD be considered as part of the solution. Creating tools and/or extensions of ourselves should not come with a set of rules that needs to be followed but rather need to be overcome. If "rules" were something to be considered, then the wheel would never have been invented! (Depending on the application of new technology, it is possible that moral concerns might need to be considered, but that is a different argument.)

The answer to the question about human time delay is mixed. It depends heavily on whether its a trained task or not.

Reminder walking for humans is a traines task. Our spinal chord is an extension of our brain and does significant "computation" (Neural reaponse to stimulus) in order to aid in balance based on feedback that would be competitive with millisecond reaction times.

Key here? Its not conscious. Our unconciscious trained and instinctual reaction times are the only thing that can rival robots. By the time we can see comprehend and make a conscious choice to respond to something we are way behind most automation.

To be clear robots with higher polling rate can also outcompete even the fastest professional athletes, so ultimately this is a technical correction. The robots will win either way even if this particular robot is only on par with the fastest unconscious human reaction speeds.

Back in the '90s the mangaka Mamoru Nagano accidentally came up with this kind of solution when he described how his mechs work. It's mostly technobabble, but the gist of it is that they're actually antigravity craft able to negate most of their weight, allowing them to carry over 100 tons of armor and equipment on two slender legs. He also described how some of the largest mechs actually needed fine controls of their antigravity equipment because they're so heavy and tall that the legs couldn't cut it as the primary balancing mechanism.

"Leonardo is not cheating while slacklining." I beg to differ. The entire challenge of slacklining is balancing yourself on a rope you're standing on without any other support. The robot using its propellers to stabilize itself is the same as if a person was holding onto another rope with their hands, the rope being suspended above their heads. "I'm not hanging from this top rope, I'm just using it to stabilize myself." vs. "Leonardo isn't using its propellers to fly, it's just using them for stability." It's the same thing.

The robot seems unimpressive otherwise, too. It's legs are so slow that it needs propellers for balance when walking. The whole thing is basically a big drone with slow, cumbersome legs attached to it. All of its abilities are based on it being a drone, not on having sophisticated legs for locomotion.
The most interesting part of it is the control system which seems to be doing a good job of balancing the thing. That being said, 20 dollar toy drones have similar systems that keep them upright and stable.

Also, the flying drone being "blown away" by the wind machine.. Facepalm. Of course it'll be blown away if the drone doesn't have a system for stationary hovering and the operator doesn't react to the wind. Any modern drone (DJI etc.) can hover in place on their own even when it's windy. Theoretically, a drone should be capable of hovering in place in a wind that matches the maximum speed of the drone.

Great video Derek! Drones are something I’ve been playing with since Covid started so it’s great to see some of that same technology used for scientific advancements. I use the same batteries, connectors, props and motors, and the flight controller for balance.  I understand the technical bits in the video, discussing the update time for the flight controller and the control link. It’s interesting they are using 200Hz control link because that is the sweet spot for drones on reaction latency and distance away. The higher Hz, the more data has to be sent and interpreted by the craft. Typically means faster reaction but at the expense of distance away from the transmitter. Lower Hz (around 50) gives more flexibility for longer distances (25+ miles from the radio). I’m interested in following this topic further so thank you for sharing!
